result.execSummary:
The defendant Amanda M Kofler was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Consecutive to any other sentence Defendant may be serving.

superMiscConds.notes: All conditions of probation shall remain in effect as conditions of Extended Supervision.

supervisions.notes: Consecutive to: any other sentence Defendant may be serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or will discharge with outstanding financial obligations due, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due.

Defendant shall have no contact with Jane Duquette or Nicole Fischer.  
Contact with Robert Sims only per approval of Probation Agent.  
Defendant shall not possess or consume any controlled substances without a valid prescription.

Defendant shall provide a DNA sample and pay the surcharge.
Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.
Defendant shall submit to random drug screens including blood, breath or urine.

chargeModifiers.descr: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime
PTAC, as a Party to a Crime

supervisions.notes: With Huber privileges consistent with the rules of the jail while the inmate maintains a minimum security status. The defendant, at the discretion of the Sheriff, may perform community service work as an inmate worker in the county jail and shall earn statutory good time for same.
